column9: This may be a life-saving drug, but the side effects, depending on your dose, can be horrible.  I had my first PE (nearly 2 dozen clots in both lungs) in Oct. 2008; in Dec. 2010 I had another round of the same thing (multiple PE). At the time of the 2nd encounter I had already spent 6 mos. on Coumadin and 325/day aspirin until it happened again. Now I'm told my condition is so severe that one more multiple clot episode will absolutely kill me (I barely survived the second) and I must be on Coumadin for the remainder of my life; I just turned 46.  The side effects from my 10 mg./day dose are horrible.  It feels like the worst flu you have ever had minus a sore throat or respiratory problems.  I have all-over body aches that are unbearable in the evenings and morning, and fevers.  My hands are always crippled and hurting and even my eyelids hurt to move in the evening.  Nobody told me of these sides until after I started reporting/complaining of them to my doc.  I did not have these before, but I also was on a lower dosage.  That's why I say it depends on your dose.  But I have been absolutely miserable for the past 3 months.  By the way, the new drug -- if you've already had a multiple PE (or 2 like me) your doc probably won't put you on it.  It works entirely different and sounds better than it really is (no blood testing, etc.).  But it's so new that most pulms won't put you on it because the risk of recurrence of multiple PE is too high (i.e. you'll die) that they prefer you stay on the tried/true/miserable drug Coumadin.  And, it doesn't have arsenic in it, but is used in very large amounts as rat poison (kills them by bleeding to death), nowhere near the therapeutic amount people are prescribed.  Hope this helps someone.

column9: I started coumadin/warfarin after a pulmonary embolism following nosebleed surgery. Prior to the nosebleed I had been diagnosed with Phlebitis of my left leg and had self medicated with aspirin for about 20 years.  About 6 mo. prior to the serious nosebleed I noted shortness of breath, so I think that i probably already had small embolisms.  After the surgery this became very pronounced and I could not even climb stairs tho I had been previously fairly fit. My Doc. had an ambulance take me to the hospital where they diagnosed the PE and put me on heparin, then warfarin.  Subsequently they tried to take me off warfarin 6 mo. later, but a PE recurred so I was put on warfarin "for life".  This allowed me to resume my regular activities including fairly vigorous activity for my age (59).  My main complaint is that my HMO's Anti-coagulation management service (AMS) kept ratcheting my dose up until I was at 60mg/week.  Then 2 weeks ago I had a very severe nosebleed that required taking my INR down to 1.0 to stop it with a 5 day hospital stay, transfusions and surgery to put in a vena cava filter to catch clots.  I think that AMS biases their dosage on the high side and am determined to see if I can't reduce it by a third to guard against more nosebleeds.  I would like to start home testing of INR so that it could be more frequent and thus allow a narrowed and lower INR target range, maybe 1.7-2.0.  I think the medical people need more studies to refine the range requirements for each type of case, since bleeding is a definite life risk.  On the other hand I am convinced that coumadin/warfarin is essential to my health/well being.

column9: I hate this medicine.  It is so difficult to get theraputic.  My hair is falling out.  I gained 20 pounds in two weeks plus I am always tired.  I hate this medicine.

The side effects of this medicine is often overlooked.  Everyone is quick to say how wonderful the medicine is, but no one takes the time to explain the side effects.  Severe hair loss, fatigue, the major changes in diet, unexplained bleeding, chest pain and let's not even mention the way that you have to be extra careful to ensure that you don't injure yourself and cause internal bleeding. Truthfully, the benefits do outweigh the side effects, but it would have been nice to have been able to prepare for them instead of experiencing them and then being told that they are normal.  My biggest problem other than the side effects is the fact that you have to take the medicine AT THE EXACT SAME TIME EVERY DAY.
